library(tidyverse)

library(drone)

data(worldbankdata)
worldbankdata

title: 2  Introduction
section: 5.1 Subset of datasets created from the worldbankdata

title: 3  A: geom_a
text:
3.1 geom_area

3.1.1 Package
ggplot2 (Wickham 2016)


3.1.2 Description
Create an area plot. This cover the space between x-axis and line that connects the data points.


3.1.3 Understandable aesthetics
alpha, colour, linetype, linewidth


3.1.4 The statistical transformation to use on the data for this layer
stat_align


3.1.5 See also
geom_line, geom_ribbon


3.1.6 Example

a1 <- worldbankdata |>
  filter(Country == "Bangladesh") |> 
  filter(Year >= 2013 & Year <= 2021) |>
  ggplot(aes(x=Year, y=Electricity)) + 
  geom_area(alpha=0.5) + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = 0.5, hjust=1)) + 
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 2013:2021) + 
  labs(title = "a1: geom_area only")

a2 <-  worldbankdata |>
  filter(Country == "Bangladesh") |> 
  filter(Year >= 2013 & Year <= 2021) |>
  ggplot(aes(x=Year, y=Electricity)) + 
  geom_area(alpha=0.5) + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = 0.5, hjust=1)) + 
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 2013:2021)  + 
  geom_point(col="red") + 
  labs(title = "a2: geom_area \n and geom_point")
a1 | a2

title: 3  A: geom_a
text:
3.2 geom_abline

3.2.1 Package
ggplot2 (Wickham 2016)


3.2.2 Description
Description Draw a straight line (\(Y=mX+c\)) for a given slope (\(m\)) and intercept (\(c\)).


3.2.3 Understandable aesthetics
Unlike most other geoms, geom_abline does not depend on the x and y variables that we map for the main plot. geom_abline has its own independent characteristics: intercept and slope.


3.2.4 The statistical transformation to use on the data for this layer
None (geom_abline is independent from the data layer.)


3.2.5 See also:
geom_point, geom_vline, geom_hline


3.2.6 Example

a1 <- ggplot(worldbankdata, aes(y = Cooking, x=Electricity)) + 
  geom_abline(intercept = 0, slope = 1) + 
  labs(title="a1: geom_abline only") +
  theme(aspect.ratio = 1)
a2 <- ggplot(worldbankdata, aes(y = Cooking, x=Electricity)) + 
  geom_abline(intercept = 0, slope = 1) + 
  geom_point() + 
  labs(title = "a2: geom_abline \n and geom_point") +
  theme(aspect.ratio = 1)
a1 | a2

title: 3  A: geom_a
text:
3.3 geom_alluvium

3.3.1 Package
ggalluvial(Brunson and Read 2019; Brunson 2020)


3.3.2 Description
Create alluvial plot. An alluvial plot is a type of diagram that is particularly useful for visualizing categorical data and the flow or transition between different categorical variables over multiple stages or categories


3.3.3 Understandable aesthetics
x, y, ymin, ymax, alpha, colour, fill, linetype, size, group (group is used internally; arguments are ignored)


3.3.4 The statistical transformation to use on the data for this layer
alluvium


3.3.5 See also
geom_stratum, geom_flow, geom_lode


3.3.6 Example

library(ggalluvial)
freq.table <- worldbankdata |>
  select(Country, Region, Year, Income) |>
  filter(Year > 2015) |>
  group_by(Region, Year, Income) |>
  summarise(n = n()) |>
  drop_na()
freq.table 

# A tibble: 153 × 4
# Groups:   Region, Year [49]
   Region               Year Income     n
   <fct>               <dbl> <fct>  <int>
 1 East Asia & Pacific  2016 LM        13
 2 East Asia & Pacific  2016 UM        10
 3 East Asia & Pacific  2016 H         14
 4 East Asia & Pacific  2017 LM        13
 5 East Asia & Pacific  2017 UM        10
 6 East Asia & Pacific  2017 H         14
 7 East Asia & Pacific  2018 LM        13
 8 East Asia & Pacific  2018 UM        10
 9 East Asia & Pacific  2018 H         14
10 East Asia & Pacific  2019 LM        12
# ℹ 143 more rows

a1 <- freq.table |>
  ggplot(aes(y = n, axis1 = Region, axis2 = Year)) +
  geom_alluvium(aes(fill = Income), width = 1/12) + 
  labs(title = "a1: geom_alluvium only")

a2 <- freq.table |>
  ggplot(aes(y = n, axis1 = Region, axis2 = Year)) +
  geom_alluvium(aes(fill = Income), width = 1/12) + 
  geom_stratum(width = 1/12, fill = "black", color = "grey") +
  geom_label(stat = "stratum", aes(label = after_stat(stratum))) +
  labs(title = "a2: geom_alluvium, \n geom_stratum and geom_label")
a1/a2

title: 3  A: geom_a
text:
3.4 geom_arc

3.4.1 Package
ggforce(Pedersen 2022)


3.4.2 Description
Draw a circle or a segment of a circle.


3.4.3 Understandable aesthetic
required aesthetics
x0 - starting coordinate of x-axis , y0 - starting coordinate of x-axis, r - radius, start, end
optional aesthetics
color, linewidth, linetype, alpha, lineend


3.4.4 The statistical transformation to use on the data for this layer
stat_arc


3.4.5 See also
geom_arc2, geom_arc_bar


3.4.6 Example

library(ggforce)
ggplot() + 
  geom_arc(aes(x0=0, y0=0, r=8, start=1, end=8)) + 
  geom_arc(aes(x0=0, y0=0, r=8, start=1, end=5), col="red",size=2) + theme(aspect.ratio = 1)

title: 3  A: geom_a
text:
3.5 geom_arc_bar

3.5.1 Package
ggforce(Pedersen 2022)


3.5.2 Description
To draw pie chart and donut chart defining centre point, a radius and a start and end angle.


3.5.3 Understandable aesthetic
required aesthetics
x0 - starting coordinate of x-axis , y0 - starting coordinate of x-axis, r - radius, start, end
optional
color, linewidth, linetype, alpha, lineend


3.5.4 The statistical transformation to use on the data for this layer
stat_arc


3.5.5 See also
geom_arc, geom_arc_bar


3.5.6 Example

df <- data.frame(
    state = c('A', 'B', 'C', 
              'D', 'E'),
    focus = c(0.2, 0, 0, 0, 0),
    start = c(0, 1, 2, 3, 4),
    end = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 2*pi),
    amount = c(4, 3, 1, 2, 5),
    stringsAsFactors = FALSE
)
ggplot(df) + 
    geom_arc_bar(aes(x0 = 0, y0 = 0, r0 = 0, r = 1, amount = amount, 
                     fill = state, explode = focus), stat = 'pie') + 
  theme(aspect.ratio = 1)








Brunson, Jason Cory. 2020. “Ggalluvial: Layered Grammar for Alluvial Plots.” Journal of Open Source Software 5 (49).


Brunson, Jason Cory, and Quentin D Read. 2019. “Package ‘Ggalluvial’.”


Pedersen, Thomas Lin. 2022. Ggforce: Accelerating ’Ggplot2’. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=ggforce.


Wickham, Hadley. 2016. Ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis. Springer-Verlag New York. https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org.

title: 10  geom_h
text:
10.1 geom_hline

10.1.1 Package
ggplot2 (Wickham 2016)


10.1.2 Description
Draw a horizontal line (\(Y=c\)) for a given value of \(c\), which is known as yintercept.


10.1.3 Understandable aesthetics
Unlike most other geoms, geom_hline does not depend on the x and y variables that we map for the main plot. geom_hline has its own independent characteristics: yintercept. The yintercept can be passed either as a arguments or aesthetic.


10.1.4 Statistics layer(s)
None


10.1.5 See also
geom_point, geom_vline, geom_hline


10.1.6 Example

a1 <- ggplot(worldbankdata, aes(y = Cooking, x= Electricity)) + geom_hline(yintercept = 50) + 
  labs(title="a1: `geom_hline` only") +
  theme(aspect.ratio = 1)

a2 <- ggplot(worldbankdata, aes(y = Cooking, x=Electricity)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_hline(yintercept = 50) + 
  labs(title="a2: `geom_point +\n geom_hline` both") +
  theme(aspect.ratio = 1)
a1 | a2




Illustration of (A) geom_hline and (B) use of geom_point and geom_hline both








Wickham, Hadley. 2016. Ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis. Springer-Verlag New York. https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org.

title: 4  geom_b
text:
4.1 geom_bar

4.1.1 Package
ggplot2 (Wickham 2016)


4.1.2 Description
Draw a bar proportional to the specified number. For example, number of cases or user defined number.


4.1.3 The statistical transformation to use on the data for this layer
stat_count - This the default statistics layer. It counts number of cases in each group.
stat_identify - It plots the data as it is.


4.1.4 See also
geom_col

4.1.4.1 With count

worldbankdata |>
  dplyr::select(c("Year", "Income")) |>
  dplyr::filter(Year==2021) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = Income)) + 
  geom_bar()




Illustration of geom_bar to create a bar chart





worldbankdata |>
  dplyr::select(c("Year", "Income", "Region")) |>
  dplyr::filter(Year==2021) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = Income, fill=Region)) + 
  geom_bar()




Illustration of geom_bar to create a stacked bar chart





worldbankdata |>
  dplyr::select(c("Year", "Income", "Region")) |>
  dplyr::filter(Year==2021) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = Income, fill=Region)) + 
  geom_bar(position = "dodge")




Illustration of geom_bar to create a cluster bar chart






4.1.4.2 With identity

dfbar <- data.frame(class=c("A", "B"),  income = c(100, 200))
ggplot(dfbar, aes(class, income)) +
  geom_bar(stat="identity")

title: 4  geom_b
text:
4.4 geom_bin2d

4.4.1 Package
ggplot2 (R-ggplot2?)


4.4.2 Description
Divides the Cartesian plane created by x-variable and y-variable into rectangles, counts the number of observations in each rectangle. Only the observations with rectangles are filled according to the number of observations.


4.4.3 Understandable aesthetics
x, y, fill, group


4.4.4 The statistical transformation to use on the data for this layer
stat_bin_2d
See also:  geom_bin_2d, geom_point
Example:

ggplot(worldbankdata, aes(y = Cooking, x=Electricity)) +
  geom_bin2d() + 
  theme(aspect.ratio = 1) +
  scale_fill_viridis()




Illustration of using geom_bin_2d

title: 4  geom_b
text:
4.3 geom_bin2d_pattern

4.3.1 Package
ggpattern(FC, Davis, and ggplot2 authors 2023)


4.3.2 Description
Divides the Cartesian plane created by x-variable and y-variable into rectangles (2D-Histogram), counts the number of observations in each rectangle. Only the observations with rectangles are filled with a pattern.


4.3.3 Understandable aesthetics
pattern_fill (pattern_* - for mapping variables under aesthetics), pattern (to set a patten, for example pattern=‘stripe’), fill, colour


4.3.4 The statistical transformation to use on the data for this layer


4.3.5 See also
geom_bin2d, geom_point

ggplot(worldbankdata, aes(y = Cooking, x=Electricity)) +
  ggpattern::geom_bin2d_pattern(bins=20) + 
  ggpattern::scale_pattern_fill_viridis_c()




Illustration of using geom_bin_2d



  theme(aspect.ratio = 1)

List of 1
 $ aspect.ratio: num 1
 - attr(*, "class")= chr [1:2] "theme" "gg"
 - attr(*, "complete")= logi FALSE
 - attr(*, "validate")= logi TRUE

title: 4  geom_b{#sec-b}
text:
4.4 See also
geom_bin2d, geom_point

ggplot(worldbankdata, aes(y = Cooking, x=Electricity)) +
  ggpattern::geom_bin2d_pattern(bins=20) + 
  theme(aspect.ratio = 1)

Warning: Removed 6051 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_bin2d()`).





Illustration of using geom_bin_2d

title: 4  geom_b
text:
4.5 geom_blank
Package:  ggplot2 (R-ggplot2?)
Description:  Draws nothing.

title: 4  geom_b{#sec-b}
text:
4.7 geom_boxplot
Package:  ggplot2 (R-ggplot2?)
Description:  Draw a bar proportional to the specified number. For example, number of cases or user defined number.

4.7.1 The statistical transformation to use on the data for this layer
stat_boxplot - This the default statistics layer. This computes minimum, maximum, median, first quartile (\(Q1\)), third quartile (\(Q3\)), upper whisker extends up to \(Q3 + 1.5 \times IQR\) and lower whisker extends up to \(Q1 - 1.5 \times IQR\), where \(IQR = Q3 - Q1\). In a notched box plot, it creates 95% confidence interval for mean.
See also:  geom_col

worldbankdata |>
  dplyr::filter(Year == 2021) |>
  dplyr::select(Cooking) |>
ggplot(aes(y = Cooking)) + 
  geom_boxplot()

Warning: Removed 37 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_boxplot()`).





Illustration of using geom_boxplot





worldbankdata |>
  dplyr::filter(Year == 2021) |>
  dplyr::select(Cooking) |>
ggplot(aes(y = Cooking)) +  
geom_boxplot(outlier.colour="black", outlier.shape=16,
             outlier.size=2, notch=TRUE)

Warning: Removed 37 rows containing non-finite values (`stat_boxplot()`).





Illustration of using geom_boxplot with changing outliers and adding a notch to create notched box plot.








Wickham, Hadley. 2016. Ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis. Springer-Verlag New York. https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org.

title: 4  geom_b
text:
4.6 geom_boxplot
Package:  ggplot2 (R-ggplot2?)
Description:  Draw a bar proportional to the specified number. For example, number of cases or user defined number.

4.6.1 The statistical transformation to use on the data for this layer
stat_boxplot - This the default statistics layer. This computes minimum, maximum, median, first quartile (\(Q1\)), third quartile (\(Q3\)), upper whisker extends up to \(Q3 + 1.5 \times IQR\) and lower whisker extends up to \(Q1 - 1.5 \times IQR\), where \(IQR = Q3 - Q1\). In a notched box plot, it creates 95% confidence interval for mean.
See also:  geom_col

worldbankdata |>
  dplyr::filter(Year == 2021) |>
  dplyr::select(Cooking) |>
ggplot(aes(y = Cooking, x=factor(0))) + 
  geom_boxplot() + 
  theme(axis.title.x=element_blank(),axis.text.x=element_blank(),axis.ticks.x=element_blank())




Illustration of using geom_boxplot





worldbankdata |>
  dplyr::filter(Year == 2021) |>
  dplyr::select(Cooking) |>
ggplot(aes(y = Cooking, x=factor(0))) +  
geom_boxplot(outlier.colour="black", outlier.shape=16,
             outlier.size=2, notch=TRUE) + 
  theme(axis.title.x=element_blank(),axis.text.x=element_blank(),axis.ticks.x=element_blank())




Illustration of using geom_boxplot with changing outliers and adding a notch to create notched box plot.








FC, Mike, Trevor L Davis, and ggplot2 authors. 2023. Ggpattern: ’Ggplot2’ Pattern Geoms.


Wickham, Hadley. 2016. Ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis. Springer-Verlag New York. https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org.
